reviews.review_title: ruined the 1st and killed Flintstones films
reviews.content: the first films was perfect, great actors for each role, the Fred as John Goodman and barney as rick moranis was perfect, and the proportions are correct, Barney was always short and smaller then Fred who was big and well built due to working at the quarry.this one the actors are poor nobodies (except Joan Collins who disappear from the acting world and only appear for bad films such as this.i don't even understand the need for the casting change? unless no one liked the film? i mean Stephen Baldwin as barney? and an English comedian as Fred? big voiced American Fred? WILLLMMMAAAAA real let down and not worth watching, just watch the first it will make you so much happier on its own

reviews.review_title: First time I ever walked out of a theater
reviews.content: My best friend and I take turns picking movies to go see.  Our first choice, Erin Brockovich (really good film btw), wasn't showing any longer and I wasn't old enough to see R-rated films.  So Flinstones was our only choice. My best friend was psyched though, he'd liked the first one (I don't remember it too well). So we sat down and began to watch this inane brain sucking movie.  About the time when that guy from Dharma and Greg offers Fred a bet or something in Vegas for Wilma...we got up and left.  I have no intention of finishing the movie.  In fact I would recommend that you avoid this like the plague!A.J.

Firstly I must say that I enjoyed the sequel to the 1994 hit film....And I was very glad they made it...Its one of the few sequels that is not only quite fun,but one I was happy to see come around.Unfortunately though, this films does have many faults. Although Kristin Johnson and jane krakowski bring Faaaaaar more sex appeal to their roles of Wilma and Betty than their 1994 counterparts, their acting doesnt seem to rise above Sitcom level which is a Bit of a Shame, but no letdown. Mark Addy as Fred flintstone struggles with the fact that he has an english accent and minimal comic talent. He certainly looks like a Young Fred and brings more depth to the Character than expected. And like the rest of the Cast, he is willing to do whatever it take to make it work which is most admirable.The Real Standouts here are Stephen baldwin as Barney..and Alan cummings as the Martian Gazoo. Whilst Rick moranis in the Original film took a more vulnerable approach to the Role,Baldwin goes after the role in the same way as the cartoon character,getting the voice pitch perfect and depicting him as the cheerful fella that the series did.Alan cummings is also very enjoyable as the Great gazoo.These two actors should take a bow for excellent performances.Thomas Gibson is a bit over the top of the scheming villain..But the sets are Great..the film is imaginative...and quite funny in many scenes...even if the ending is a Bit predictable(ONE QUESTION...HOW DID BARNEY SHRINK SO MUCH BETWEEN THIS FILM AND THE ORIGINAL....JUST A THOUGHT)All in All...a great effort guys...Im so Happy this film was made..cause when the first one came out....it was more than just a film...it was a special event....and this film was the icing on the Cake....I GIVE IT 9 OUT OF 10......GREAT EFFORT

reviews.review_title: A big, bright, noisy, colourful mess.
reviews.content: This second live action rendition of the animated cartoon by Hanna-Barbera seems to be uncertain of whom its audience is -- there is scatological humour for the kids (and like-minded adults), romance, song-and-dance routines, a Mick Jagger impersonator -- but the whole melange didn't really mesh into a cohesive whole.The story of how Fred (Mark Addy) and the perfectly cast Barney (Stephen Baldwin) meet, woo, and eventually conquer the hearts of Wilma (Kristen Johnston) and Betty (the incomparable Jane Krakowski) is over-involved and too convoluted for small children; but the bright colours and action kept the kids at the matinee we were at quiet -- for the most part.Joan Collins as Wilma's scheming mother (and her FABULOUS costumes) was an absolute delight to the eye.  Harvey Korman as her father did little more than grunt occasionally.There were some good sight gags and jokes, and the inevitable stone and rock puns, but they were all aimed at the adults.Kids raised on Pokeman and Nickelodeon are not going to really enjoy this movie -- but they will probably beg their parents to take them and Mom and Dad will enjoy it more than the kids will.

smoke a bowl to.wow i mean if you watch it any other way your gonna want to anyway. this is garbage everyone knows it even those of you who gave this movie a 10.so with that being said anyone who did like this movie please do yourself a favor and go get bedrock bowling for the playstation youll probably think its good too.everyone who took part in making this thing of a movie should be blacklisted from hollywood for at least the next five years as punishment for this crap called cinema ;)~~~

It kind of surprises me that this straight to video type sequel that overall is rather predictable and just a tad lame got as much good comment as it did. It has been on cable a lot recently in my area, and that is the best place to see it ... and I have yet to see the whole movie. Why would I? The story is predictable, the writing and acting not inspired, and (as someone else said) not loyal to the series. Aside from Wilma, the casting was pretty good, but couldn't they do better than the tired storyline? A few of the jokes were cute too ... the Juraissac Park and Barney not realizing what Betty meant by taking him home and making him breakfast is two that come to mind (though a bit racy for the kiddies).  The "look" is inferior though ... it's expensive to keep up the faux BC look, and this movie was not likely to have the funds to do so.  Overall, ok cable fare, and maybe the kids will like it, but not worth $4 from Blockbuster.-j

This movie isn't as bad as people make it out to be, but it isn't great either.  The movie was made for children, not adults, so keep that in mind when watching it.For me, it would have been a tad better without the incredibly lame fart jokes, but thats just me.
I gave this thing 3 stars for Dino! Best character in this absolute disaster of a movie. Dino actually made me kind of chuckle. Why, oh why did they bother?

This film is good cartoon fun. No wasted scenes; it is short enough that it never drags. Harvey Korman gives the movie a connection with the original series (1960s). Joan Collins and Jane Krakowski brighten up any movie. The character Gazoo helps to solidify the plot. The humor is cute and in good taste. The set designs are colorful and clever; they keep every scene lively.I have only two criticisms. The resolutions to the main conflicts are a little too easy.Also, they should have let Jane Krakowski sing (perhaps instead of Mick Jagged). Jane is an excellent singer; she is probably the biggest talent in the cast. Jane K. has an on-camera charisma that begs comparison to Marilyn Monroe, and her body language is always flawless and engaging.

reviews.review_title: Another Feel-Good summer movie that was dumped by critics (casino owners and members of The Rockefeller family clan, I guess!))
reviews.content: As an old Flintstones fan I was impressed by the first film adaptation in 1994, but this one works even better for me. This time the cast is not as expensive, but the actors are likeable and effective. The sets, the costumes and stuff are fantastic. And even CGI is good (I don't care about good CGI though, bad CGI has more heart in my opinion). The Flintstones series were a TV product and it has TV program rythm and dynamics. I don't know about the big screen, it looks and feels great on the cozy coach with my wife, cat and some fried chicken. I wish there were more series with this cast. I rate it 10, and I mean it. Maybe I would rate it 5/10 in the year 2000, but today it's 10. You know what I mean: look into the window and the watch this.

reviews.review_title: My Fun-Filled Experience with The Flintstones
reviews.content: I thought this movie was really well done. This is not an average "kiddie film", its a wonderful family treat! The characters were portrayed quite accurately, too. The film left me with quite a bright feeling inside. I recommend this well-written, well-acted, sometimes self-referential film to all that enjoy this type of material! If you haven't seen it yet, go check it out!

reviews.review_title: Yabba Dabba Doo What Thou Wilt!
reviews.content: I know I'm swimming against the tide here, but it must be said. I've seen Viva Rock Vegas as well as the first Flintstones movie, and I actually prefer the former. I thought that the actors were much better suited to their respective roles (e. g., Rosie O'Donnel as Betty? What were they smoking when that idea hit?!?), and it was overall funnier than the first.Sure, the storyline was stupid--it's based on a cartoon show, after all, NOT Shakespeare!--but so was the series. Had there been some way for the producers to have the same infinitely repeating scenery that Hanna/Barbera used, it would have been just about perfect.Also, casting Harvey Korman (the original Great Gazoo) as Wilma's father was pretty neat.

reviews.review_title: The actors are truer to the cartoon originals.
reviews.content: I was disappointed with the 1996 film, I felt that the Betty, Wilma and Barney characters were too far away from the cartoon characters. This has largely been put right in "Viva Rock Vegas". Apart from this the prequel is inferior to the 1996 film. The plot is not as good, and you are always aware that what you are watching as a film set, something which I don't remember feeling about the 1996 film.

The Flinstones in Viva Rock Vegas: 3.9 out of 10? This sequel to the 1994 hit The Flinstones, actually takes place before the first one. Fred and Barney havn't met Wilma and Betty in this movie. It starts off as Fred & Barney single, and later, they meet Wilma and Betty. They start dating and after a while ,they become GOOD "friends". At Wilmas dads birthday celebration, the people are xtremly rude. So Wilmas old boyfriend, Chip Rockifellar, offers them a trip to Rock Vegas. He ends up using Fred and makes it look like he stole Wilmas Pearls. This sequel was supposed to be not very good and a lot worse than the first. It was good and it wasn't as good as the first ,but it was still cute. A very fun family/ comedy that everyone can enjoy!Fun! 7/10The Flinstones 2 wasn't a bad PG. Their wasn't any innuendo except for maybe a little crude humor and their wasn't any profaintity.

As others have said, this isn't funny. Everyone knows the movie will end with Fred and Wilma, and Barney and Betty getting married. We also know the names of their (future) kids.This "prequel" disrupts the history established by the 1994 movie. Wilma's dad is an idiot, so why is he married to to Pearl? And the Great Gazoo is just annoying.Three extra stars because Wilma is played by the 6' dazzling beauty, Kristen Johnston. Otherwise, I'd give this 0 stars!

I thought it was a good movie, but not because of the laughs.  It can teach kids that when they grow up, they don't have to marry rich and famous people, just whoever comes naturally. Some of the jokes suck, in fact, I never laughed the entire film, I just thought it was OK.   For sexual content, well, it's hard to tell if Fred slept with Wilma (the same with Barney and Wilma), and there is a gay (literally) joke where Gazoo (voiced by Alan Cumming, that annoying bird from the first one), who must observe our mating rituals and dosen't understand that it is boys and girls, asks Barney and Fred to mate. I didn't think they had enough "character development" on Rock Vegas, and I wish they had told more about the flight there.  But all in all, it's an OK film (though not much of a comedy), Beetles fans look out for a spoof of them, too.

This film pales to the original.  I gave it a '2' because the movie previews before the feature attraction were so good.  The cast wasn't all that great. The plot and story line were weak.  The special effects were right out of "The Muppet Movie."  Save your hard-earned "clams" and take Bam-Bam and Pebbles to see "EL DORADO."

I REALLY enjoyed the first film, and was skeptical of seeing this one with a different cast.  I must admit, THIS Fred actually did a better job than John Goodman, however I miss Elizabeth Perkins as Wilma.  I thought Steven Baldwin (A Baldwin playing a Barney...lol) did a pretty good job as Barney, and I can't decide which Barney rules, Rick Moranis or Steven.  OK, Rosie O'Donnell ROCKS as Betty, this one was a good attempt, but it just wasn't Rosie. My only complaint with the film was the sexual comments made.  Betty invited Barney over to her appartment to have sex, and the Great Gazoo was sent to earth to study man's MATEING ritual, And He tells Barney and Fred to "Go to it" as Barney is laying on top of Freds backside.  Barny starts cleaning a girl's chest area after he makes a mess, and to Betty who see's, it appears that Barny is PLAYING with the womans breasts. This is suppose to be a FAMILY film, and I found this material VERY unacceptable for my two daughters. I thought Alan Cumming was WONDERFUL as the Great Gazoo, this was a breakout performance. The plot was very good, (However, they never did explain Fred being cleared of his framed crime, or escaping from jail, and the issue of the stolen pearls was never resolved),the acting was great, (considering it WAS A CARTOON), and the special effects were not bad either. There were no laugh out loud jokes, but I did smirk a couple of times, it was enjoyable, but be warned before taking your small children, unless you're ready to answer some sexual questions.

reviews.review_title: DO NOT spend your time watching this sorry excuse for an attempt at a film
reviews.content: I really can't say much about this travesty... but even if I could, I'd probably refuse to give this movie anything else.  I'll elaborate SLIGHTLY on the sad butchering of the Hannah-Barbarah classic...  THEY DIDN'T ACT LIKE THE CHARACTERS.  THEY DIDN'T ACT AT ALL.  THEY LOST THE FOCUS OF THE PLOT.  THEY DIDN'T KNOW HOW TO EDIT EVEN....... aaaaaaaaaahhhhhhhhhhh! (okay, I'm done)

reviews.review_title: A Poor Excuse For A Flintstone Movie!
reviews.content: As a fan who grew up in the 60s with the tv show, I take my Flintstones very seriously. I enjoyed the 1994 movie. It made me laugh. But this one? Ugh! My first complaint is with Stephan Baldwin playing Barney. I thought he was trying too hard to act and sound like Barney. He just came across as goofy! I didn't think Harvey Korman should have had a part in the first movie and defiantly not this one! He was like a joke and I hated that! Rosie O'Donnell should not have been in this one either! I thought the other actors were great, but the script was a little messed up. Why was Alan Cummings playing plural roles?! Come on, guys! Fred and Barney switching dates was in poor taste, too! Who thought that mess up?! My last gripe is Ann-Margaret singing Viva Rock Vegas! I love her, she has a great voice, but this was not her song! She was great with Elvis in the 1960s Viva Las Vegas and that was good enough! Imo, Alan Cummings did a great job with the song. They should have let his version be played in the plane ride scene to Rock Vegas! I'm done. Ouch! I have a headache! LOL!

reviews.review_title: A Pay-Per-View I Wished I Didn't Get
reviews.content:
I am usually not harsh... but this movie was just horrible!
It's as if the set designer made no attempt to try and fool us. At least with the first one the set had more of a realistic feel if you will. The set designers took a vacation with this one. It was so horrible.The story line was... I can't even waste my time typing how bad it was as well.I truly counted the minutes till it would end. I wanted to change the station so badly, but I paid 2.99 for it and darn it.. I will get what I paid for. (Tho I think I overspent on this one)HOWEVER....I always try and find something from a film that was positive and in this film I will say it was Alan Cumming. His Gazoo & Mick Jagged gave me my only smirk from this film. Alan is extremely talented, and I am sorry he was attached to such a horrible film, but had it not been for him, I would have been in a coma....This one isn't even worth watching on HBO... and I hope it never goes on Network TV, because they'd be hard pressed to get advertisers....Thank you ALAN CUMMING....

reviews.review_title: The First Movie Sucked! But This Sequel ROCKS!
reviews.content: This film is great! It's not so much a sequel to the first movie, it's more of a 'replacement' to it and it really does outdo it! Mark Addy is good as Fred Flinstone and it's a really bright enjoyable flick. Adults maybe are being aware too much, but this isn't just a dumb, colourful show for 3 year olds, it has a good story and plenty of gags throughout which everyone will enjoy. As I said, I hated the first movie, but I really enjoyed this one. It's so COLOURFUL and HAPPY and BRIGHT and SNAPPY and PLAYFUL and Joyful and...LOL. 8/10 :-)

No, this movie isn't great.  But movies that you can take the whole family to see are getting fewer and fewer.  This is an entertaining, fun, family movie. Give the kids an appreciation for the funny cartoon characters so many of us grew up with.  I think this one is better than the first live-action Flinstones movie.

When I was watching this movie I was reminded of The Honeymooners which the Flintstones were based on. When you watch Mark Addy as Fred you can see a lot of Jackie Gleason's mannerism and character of Ralph Crandom. Therefore I can see I movie of THE GREAT ONE'S LIFE being made in the future with Mr. Addy portraying Jackie Gleason. As for Stephen Baldwin portraying Barney I didn't care for his performance. I think they should have stuck with Rick Moranis or a younger version of Rick Moranis. Now for another comparison of this movie and the first one is that I preferred Jane Krakowski's performance of Betty more than I liked Rosie O'Donnell's performance

reviews.review_title: I live it and don't know why.
reviews.content: I understand why people don't like this movie because of the B list actors and they're really cheap filters that it has to make it look the way it does but I think it's really a great movie because it really looks like a cartoon and yeah the first movie was perfect with Moranis and Goodman but these two have chemistry as well so I think overall it's still an eight as well as it's nostalgic because let's face it there's never gonna be another Flintstones movie.

This is not only a bad movie based on a cartoon. This isn't even just a bad prequel. This is wrong on one two many levels. The acting is the worst I've ever seen. The story is so clichéd.You know Fred & Wilma marry in the end just like in the cartoon. And Gazoo is probably the "worst" character ever to be put in a movie. It's stupid as far as all movies go. I hated this movie. That's right. This is worse than The Last Airbender, Saving Christmas & Jack & Jill rolled into one movie. Under any standards of movies, this is definitely on an insulting level to not just me, but the movie lovers, Flintstones fans, & people that just hate movies. Don't watch this movie. You're better off with The Last Airbender, Saving Christmas & Jack & Jill. I'd give this movie a zero if that was an option. Worst Movie Ever.

reviews.review_title: Take the good with the bad
reviews.content: This movie was really hard to rate.  At times I could easily have given it an 8 because of the fantastic sets, effects, costumes, acting, and dialogue. Of course, I could also drive it down at times because of all of those same reasons.  Either way, much better than the original (even without Halle Berry) and much more to the original series.

I didn't like this PREQUEL! Why didn't they make a sequel to the '94 smash hit!? Well, let me take this by the cast and let you be the judge.Mark Addy: What happened to John Goodman? I know they wanted Fred to look a little younger. SO WHAT?? Dress John Goodman up to where he would look young. I am ashamed of him.Stephen Baldwin: Not Rick Moranis -- but still pretty good none the less.I am disappointed in this. And after all that waiting for the next Flintsontes movie...3.

reviews.review_title: Fine for kids and Flintstone fans, BUT BEWARE OF THE GREAT GAZOO!!!!
reviews.content: As a fan of "The Flintstones" I found myself enjoying the filmmakers bring Bedrock back to the big screen. Fans will Love it and kids will too!! however parents should be cautioned to the presence of The Great Gazoo [Played {Wonderfully} By Alan Cumming] some children in the theatre were frightened of him despite his happy disposition. I was very impressed with Stephen Baldwin as Barney Rubble he truly brought the character to life, more so than his predecessor, Rick Moranis.
Took an awful movie, and made it so much worse.
Wait, this has a better tomato score than the superior first one ?

But then I wasn't too impressed with the original. The entire cast is new, and they actually seem to fit the movie better. Also, this film has a much more developed storyline and actually deals with the origins of the two main families.

Wilma runs away from her snobby rich family and her associates, and winds up in a diner meeting Betty, a waitress working there. Shortly after, they meet Fred and Barney, and during their double date, Fred is with Betty and Barney is with Wilma, but shortly afterward the couples switch partners. Also, Gazoo the alien appears to them, doing a study of human mating rituals, and he tags along with them, though he is an annoyance to Fred and the others.

But the casino they patronize is run by a ex-boyfriend of Wilma's who wants to marry Wilma-not for love, but for access to her family's money. He tries to sabotage the relationship between Fred and Wilma-will he succeed? Ironically, while the original movie was a hit, this one wasn't, even though it improved on the original. Too bad they couldn't have made animated versions instead.
This prequel of the Flintstones live-action flick just doesn't count as a real film.
It's better than the original

The design is still impressive, and the story is much more in the vein of the show…but this new casting is embarrassing. The four leads look like they're being held hostage; it's never a good sign when Stephen Baldwin is the standout. Rosie O'Donnell returns, but doesn't get to reprise her solid performance as Betty. And why did Hollywood put all their chips on Alan Cumming at the turn of the century? No one won from that bet…including Cumming.

A really unnecessary prequel to The Flintstones (1994), but one that has some decent things about it. The movie is about Fred Flinstone (Mark Addy) and Barney Rubble (Stephen Baldwin) who are visited by The Great Gazoo (Alan Cumming). This is about as random as a plot as we can get. Gazoo has been sent to Earth to learn about the earthlings mating rituals. Only Fred and Barney can see him and truthfully he doesn't even need to be in this movie. Also the effects to show him look very very bad. Anyways Fred and Barney one day get some food and run into Berry O'Shale (Jane Krakowski) and Wilma Slaghoople (Kristen Johnston). Wilma has run away from her lavish live in Slaghoople manor and is currently living with Betty. The four of them decide to go on a double date and both basically come out of it with their respective partners. Wilma brings her new found friends to her family for her father Colonel Slaghoople's (Harvey Korman) birthday where Fred meet's Wilmas ex-boyfriend Chip Rockefeller (Thomas Gibson). Chip invited them all to his new casino opening in Rock Vegas. Fred agrees they should go with hopes of winning enough money to buy Wilma a proper ring and propose to her. The four of them go, but meanwhile Chip is actually the puppet master here planning to get Wilma back and get rid of Fred. There's a bit more to it all, but that's the jist of it. So yeah the plot is basically an origin story of how Fred and Barney met Wilma and Betty. Why they added the Gazoo plotline I have no idea. Looks like they just wanted to make more references to the cartoon. The film does actually have some funny moments and some adult jokes in it like the previous one which I actually laughed out loud at. I will say Mark Addy is definitely no John Goodman. He's sufficient, but he just is kinda missing something here as Fred. I thought Stephen Baldwin was a good Barney and I even liked Jane Krakowski as Betty. I think Kristen Johnson as Wilma was miscast. She's very much out of place in this movie and while she's trying her best I think they could have gone with someone else of this role. Definitely, a forgettable film. If you have to watch one terrible Flintstones movie might as well just stick to the original (as I said previously I think it's a decent flick). This one's also streaming on HBO for anyone curious.

More juvenile than the first film with tons of Batman & Robin-esque homoeroticism ("Have a gay old time") and actually having the audacity to bring the infamous alien that ruined the show for many into this movie - now with a creepy face superimposed over a creepy CGI character - The Flintstones in Viva Rock Vegas has decent performances and still feels like an episode of the show coming to life, with most of the actors looking like their cartoon counterparts despite the fact that only one of them returns from the first film and even then, she's voicing a different character but the lingering questions this prequel answers just aren't as interesting as the embezzlement plot from the first film (itself way too mature subject matter for the target audience to begin with). Won't be revisiting this live-action adaptation of a cartoon anytime soon.
A feel good film, brilliant for all the family.
Wow. Viva Rock Vegas is not only one of the most nonsensical puns I've ever heard in my life, but the film itself is very uninspired and somehow manages to be worse than its predecessor.

A steaming pile of dino crap, The Flintstones in Viva Rock Vegas is an extraordinary dumb and formulaic goofball comedy.  Set as a prequel to the 1994 blockbuster, Wilma Slaghoople, the daughter of a rich family, feels trapped in her high society life and runs off to Bedrock were she meets Fred Flintstone and falls in love.  Additionally, the Great Gazoo is introduced; a small green alien with superpowers who no one but Fred and Barney can see.  The plot is just terrible, hitting every bad rom-com cliché and trope in the book.  And the caveman jokes are incredibly lame.  Also, the casting is awful; particularly Kristen Johnston as Wilma.  Humorless dreck, The Flintstones in Viva Rock Vegas is an insult to Flintstone fans everywhere.
total and utter crap

Unnecessarily pointless as both a prequel and an origin story. The improved special effects are an step forward from the original, but "The Flintstones in Viva Rock Vegas" takes a clumsy step back with poor casting choices and a script just as awful as its 1994 predecessor.
It baffles me why this piece of crap exists.

I see where and why this film coped a lot of slack but I honestly enjoyed it just as much as I did when I was a kid. Sure the first live-action Flintstones film was better but this one is still highly entertaining and certainly stays true toI see where and why this film coped a lot of slack but I honestly enjoyed it just as much as I did when I was a kid. Sure the first live-action Flintstones film was better but this one is still highly entertaining and certainly stays true to the cartoon in a lot of ways. There are a lot of funny witty jokes that really make the film as well as just being a bright colourful film to watch. Corny, yes and quite a bit too, but not in a way that ruins the movie, but some won't like it others will.
Even Worse Than The 94 MovieWith mediocre performances, Pretty bad humour, and overall boring, Viva Rock Vegas is not a “rockin” good time.

I always liked the "Flintstones" cartoon and I was able to appreciate some aspects of the 1994 live-action movie. However, this movie was a disgrace in every details. Running as a prequel to the first film and the cartoon itself, it shows howI always liked the "Flintstones" cartoon and I was able to appreciate some aspects of the 1994 live-action movie. However, this movie was a disgrace in every details. Running as a prequel to the first film and the cartoon itself, it shows how the four main characters (Flintstones and Rubbles) met and married, after a trip to the city of Rock Vegas (the equivalent, in the movie and Flintstones world, to the city of Las Vegas, of course). But the thing that really make me mad in this movie, personally, was that silly, green character, that seems to have come out of the "Jetsons" (another Hanna-Barbera cartoon). He was permanently out of context, his existence has been poorly explained by the plot and he only served to try to make totally empty jokes. I wanted to drown that alien several times while watching the movie.If the 1994 movie had already revealed several fragilities, beginning with an all-too-adult plot for a children-oriented film, this movie completely misses any attempt to improve these faults. The plot is miserably poor, which is probably the result of poor scriptwriting choices and the subliminal, lousy, intention of extorting some more box office money (we cannot forget the huge box-office success that the first film was). A bad choice: the public wisely didn't pay to watch this piece of trash. Dried jokes, a bad plot, poor acting, bad construction of characters, far-fetched props and sets, a tiring cinematography and a cast that did an absolutely painstaking job. For all this, this is one of the worst family movies I've ever seen.

rt_summary: Fred Flintstone, the boy from the wrong side of the rocks, courts the beautiful, young heiress Wilma Slaghoople. Along with best friend Barney Rubble, and his future fiancee Betty, Fred and Wilma head off for a romantic weekend in Rock Vegas, the hottest rock resort on the continent.
meta_summary: The Flintstones and the Rubbles go on vacation to Rock Vegas, where Wilma is pursued by a playboy. This is a live-action prequel to 1994's "The Flintstones."
